body:
## About caching without a lockfile

I think using caching without having a `package-lock.json` file is going to cause problems sooner or later...
As it stand now, I can only tell GitHub action to refresh the cache whenever the `package.json` file is changed.

If a peer-dependency or transient dependency updates, it will not change the `package.json` file. (A `package-lock` file would definitely change!). Now the GitHub Action runner is using old stuff!

## If you want to cache, use a lock-file

I think caching is only a good idea if you're actually using a lock-file.
This will also have the added benefit of making the build reproducible.

If you're scared of having to deal with package-lock updates manually, you could consider migrating to Renovate bot instead, and update the lockfile via a automated PR once a week.

Or you can just not use the cache functionality. ðŸ˜„ 
That **might** slow down the tests a bit, but you're not messing around with a lock file either.

I'll leave you to decide how to weigh this.
